text: [Applause]
look around you the graduating class of
the Harvard Business School
accomplished brilliant distinguished
toned no seriously you're all an
incredibly good shape and it relates to
my story I entered HBS as a truly
untraditional applicant morbidly
obese this isn't a place that was built
for the big and tall from squeezing Us
in to narrow rows in our Aldrich
classrooms to 5K charity runs every
weekend it's easy to feel like an
outsider here in fact and I've ran the
numbers on this there's a 25% chance
that the person sitting next to you is a
former
Olympian and while I might not be one
yet I'm getting there over the course of
the past year I've lost over a 100
[Applause]
pound I wanted to share with you my
story and the three lessons that HBS has
taught me thank you for giving me the
chance this is truly an honor
my weight my whole life was what I would
consider a nuisance always there
something I was a bit uncomfortable with
but not so much so that I was entirely
willing to change it in fact it wasn't
until right before I left my job to
attend HBS that it dawned on me that my
weight could have much broader
implications in a meeting with a mentor
on my last day at work he decided to
impart some advice he told me that I
should lose weight at HBS so that
employers would be interested in hiring
me because if I'm not smart enough to
know what to put into my mouth I can't
possibly be that
smart two things occurred to me then
first that he's a jerk I mean seriously
who says that last day of work I
me but more importantly I realized then
that without knowing it I had placed
conditions on my life that could prevent
me from reaching my
goals many of us create situations that
hold us back artificially from being our
authentic selves and many of us will
continue to do so we'll rent a
particularly expensive one-bedroom
apartment in New York City and use that
as the reason that we can't leave the
job we hate we'll construct a group of
friends and convince ourselves that we
have to live a certain lifestyle to keep
up with them or we'll put creating a
family on hold
because we have a road map for our
career and we can't deviate from it I'm
not saying that these issues have no
truth to them but we're often creating a
false dichotomy we have more than two
extreme options it would be easy to me
for me to make this the part of the
speech where I tell you to do what you
love the fact is most of us probably
still don't know what that is and even
if we think we know it'll probably
change over time so instead of of saying
that I'll say this as much as possible
don't add layers of artificial fat
around yourself that prevent you from
reaching your goals allow yourself the
flexibility to learn what you love to
figure out where you create the most
value and to get there put as few
roadblocks as possible in the way for
those of you keeping count that's the
first
lesson I've got some good news and some
bad news for you the bad news is that it
takes a heck of a lot of courage to
change the things that that we don't
love in our lives even if we we've
limited the amount of roadblocks in our
way the good news is that we've all had
at least 2 years of training in learning
how to be
courageous we've all heard that HBS is
transformational I don't know about you
but I had no idea what alumni really
meant when they said that but I get it
now and for me the HBS transformation
was not only emotional and intellectual
but also
physical when I talk about finding
courage here at HBS I'm talking about a
process not an event the process begins
the first time we raise our hand in our
first class unsure that we can actually
add value in a setting where we are
convinced we were the one admissions
mistake then we get our first cold call
I'm sure we all remember it well in fact
because of my particularly unsettling
experience I can never hear the name
Jack Welch again without breaking into a
cold
sweat which to be fair is probably
exactly what J Welch would
want and the journey continues from the
first time you realize a belief you had
long held was wrong and you admit it to
the moment you are sitting in a foreign
country during field two and you realize
that you have to solve a real company's
real problems in less than a
week every day during these two years
we've practiced what it's like to do
something we weren't sure we were
capable of when we imagine courage it's
easy to imagine someone saving a family
from a burning building I hope we don't
fall into the Trap of only seeing
courageous opportunities in these
moments because God willing most of us
won't have the chance to display it
there I'd instead like to provide some
alternative examples of Courage that I
have personally seen here at
HBS courage is military veterans sharing
their experiences in combat their real
innermost thoughts and feelings with a
bunch of section mates who could not
even begin to understand courage is
standing in front of a room of 90 peers
who feel like family and voicing the
frustrations of a group who feel
ignored courage is a brand new HBS
Professor younger than some of her
students teaching her very first class
on her very first
day courage is a student who asks for
tutoring help in an environment of 900
people who have seemed to have never
struggled once in their academic careers
and courage is one woman who wakes the
entire School up to the fact that gender
relations still have a long way to go at
HBS this place may not create courage
but it certainly cultivates its growth
and that in my opinion is the core of
the transformational experience
here in my case courage was a section
mate asking me honestly what had kept me
overweight and courage was then me
battling the urge to be defensive
something I believe I had been for a
long time about this issue and taking a
hard honest look Within Myself to figure
out what have prevented change I won't
claim it was one introspective session
or one conversation that made this
weight loss successful when so many
hadn't been in the
past I think this
success was the outgrowth of the growth
that had occurred while I was here at a
BS I finally believed that I could
achieve something that for a long time
seemed Out Of Reach and I was finally
ready to ask for the help and support
that I needed to make it through the
Journey
successfully so here's lesson number two
if you use a broad lens you'll see
opportunities for courage everywhere you
go after you leave this place you'll
certainly see it when you evaluate your
life and your career but you'll probably
ALS also see it in the communities
you're a part of or the company you work
for if you see a person or a group of
people doing something that feels wrong
to you I encourage you to ask those
uncomfortable questions and to take
action even if doing so is
unpopular HBS talks a lot about creating
leaders who make a difference in the
world being a leader in those
particularly tough situations when it is
so much easier to do nothing that is
where we can make a difference and we
can all do that we have a responsibility
to do
that if I can leave you with one more
lesson from my experience it's this be
full of gratitude and make sure not to
get distracted by endlessly comparing
yourselves to others we have a tradition
here at Harvard Business School
hopefully many of you in the audience
have had a chance to be a part of it we
give a standing ovation to family
members who come to visit
class it's a unique tradition that I've
never heard of outside of
HBS we do it because we realize that we
could have never done this without you
you every single one of you in this
audience in fact this might be a good
time to give you a true HBS welcome
on behalf of everyone here thank you
thank you for helping us with our
homework for making us go to school when
we didn't seem all that sick for
cheering with us when things went well
and for bolstering us up when things
didn't thank you also so so much for for
paying off our graduate school
loans you're welcome class of 2013 that
was binding I have seen at least three
episodes of Law and Order uh that was a
verbal
contract in all seriousness we are one
small piece of so many who have come
before
us it is so profoundly easy to compare
yourself with others and let's be honest
HBS helps us fall into this trap I mean
there's a spreadsheet you can download
load to not only compare your s salary
to the average graduate salary but even
to different percentiles of graduate
salaries by the way here is a pro tip do
not compare yourself to the 95th
percentile it is depressing just
entirely resist that
urge I'm not saying it's inherently
wrong to compare yourself with others in
fact often times this comparison can
drive us to
Greatness the real problem is is that we
don't often use the right comparables
and if Finance has taught me at least
one thing it's that the comps we choose
really
matter now that I'm 100 pound down I
found myself falling into the Trap of
comparing myself to everyone else at
HBS if I compare bmis I'm still in
pretty bad shape compared to the rest of
you but that's the wrong measure when I
focus on the right things the amount of
change Within Myself the distance that
I've come on my own Journey that's when
I realize that I'm on the right track
and I'd Rob myself of the joy of this
experience if I focused only on the
numbers as we move forward how can we
possibly possibly compare ourselves to
others on the dimensions that matter how
positively we've affected our
communities or how satisfied we are with
the impact we are making through our
work and our families the amount of cash
we have or the size of our house are
both pretty poor indicators of what
we've accomplished but they're the
easiest to measure and I know that we
can do better than that so to the class
of
2013 it has been quite the ride and I
wouldn't have traded these two years for
anything remember how I said at the
beginning of the speech that it could
have been easy for me to feel like an
outsider here in the land of the petite
and the toned
I never did and that's because of you
thank you for accepting me as I was and
as I am you've given me so much so let
me give you something back to that end I
ask that you please remember these three
things keep your life trim of
constraints remember and exercise the
courage that you have practiced here and
stay grateful for the many blessings in
your life thank you very much
you're phenomenal
